Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Statistical Properties of Nonequilibrium Dynamical Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Conference on Statistical Properties of Nonequilibrium Dynamical Systems will be held from August 1 through August 5, 2016, at the Academy of Mathematics and Systems Science (AMSS) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, in Beijing China. The conference will be an integrated, collaborative research program aimed to significantly increase our understanding of the statistical properties of dynamical systems of physical origin. The conference topics are central to equilibrium and non-equilibrium physical systems, with applications to the theory of gases, mixing of fluids, diffusion and transport phenomena. They involve novel classes of systems and methods of analysis which have the potential to produce significant progress in our understanding of certain general types of stochastic and deterministic dynamical systems.

The goal of the conference is to bring together an excellent group of researchers from around the world to discuss new research results, explore new ideas and powerful new mathematical tools to deepen our theoretical understanding of the dynamical underpinnings of non-equilibrium systems and classical statistical physics. Progress in this area would significantly improve both our conceptual understanding of physical systems and our ability to predict their behavior. While successful collaborations have taken place among subsets of the participants, the conference will provide a valuable opportunity for these international researchers to gather and have face to face discussions. The organizers will take the opportunity to encourage more young researchers and junior faculties to work on dynamical systems and related research topics.

The conference webpage is: http://people.math.umass.edu/~hongkun/conference2016.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Conference Grant was used to support participants for two conferneces and one workshop:

(1) The International Conference on "Statistical Properties of Non-equilibrium Dynamical Systems" was held in the Southern University of Science and Technology (SUSTech) at Shenzhen, China, from July 27 to August 2, 2016 in conjunction with a workshop from July 11 to July 26, 2016. This program was jointly hosted by SUSTech and the U.S. National Science Foundation.

(2) The conference on "Mathematical Physics Perspective of Billiards and Dominoes" was held at University of Massachusetts Amherst, from September 22-23, 2017. This program was jointly hosted by  the U.S. National Science Foundation, Department of Mathematics & Statistcis at University of Massachusetts Amherst, the Springer Science+Business Media LLC, and the International Association of Mathematical Physics.

A number of plenary talks were given in both conferences by an impressive group of distinguished researchers, including Yakov Sinai -- recipient of the Abel Prize and Gregory Margulis -- Fields medalist; together with several parallel sessions of short talks given by a group of junior participants, including graduate students and post-docs. The workshop and conference created an integrated, collaborative event whose purpose was to significantly increase our understanding of the statistical properties of dynamical systems of physical origin. Besides the invited international distinguished experts, there are many excellent researchers in dynamical systems affiliated with more than ten universities in China, including Peking University, Southern University of Science and Technology, University of science and technology of china, Soochow University, etc. The conference and workshop provided a great opportunity for mathematicians from the USA and other countries to communicate and exchange ideas with them. 

The conference and workshop addresses fundamental scientific problems including the nature of non-equilibrium steady states and transport processes in physics, chemical engineering and other sciences. The collaborations in the conference and workshop have significantly developed the foundations of non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, and have drawn significant attention from the broader scientific community.
